text: I'm Sarah Gavron the director of
suffragette so this is the laundry in
Bethnal Green where our central
character for film Lord Watts works
she's played by Carey Mulligan and this
was a we shot this in a deserted print
factory just outside London and our
production designer brought in his
machinery to create this world and these
laundries were almost like the
sweatshops of the day they were very
harsh environments women worked very
long hours
here's more leaving to go into central
London to deliver a package and we
wanted to juxtapose the worlds of East
London the hardscrabble worlds of
working London with the grandeur of
central London she's getting on a bus
here we could only find one 1912 bus so
the visual effects people had to
replicate and create a lot of more buses
for us and this is a street we closed
off in central London called Corn Hill
and the sequence here is based on a
historical event when the suffragettes
went to central London in disguise just
addressed as ordinary women and hid in
their prams and under their mouths and
in their bags toffee hammers and stones
and then at the strike of the clock all
brought them out and smashed the windows
along the central London shopping
streets as a form of protest in their
fight to get the vote for women and here
we see Lord there's not yet Asaf reject
and has no idea that this protest is
going to happen looking in a shop window
it was the era of consumerism just
beginning so Lord is here looking at a
woman who has a very different life from
her and the protest is about to take
place and it was a it was very
shocking when this happened at the time
and caused great chaos when we were
shooting it we had to and as well as
filming in the central under the street
we had to build some shop fronts and a
parking lot so that we could break the
glass and we storyboarded the whole
sequence meticulously we wanted it to
sort of have a feeling of Battle of
Algiers and taking
surprise and the cameras handheld we had
three cameras on this day one on a crane
and two on the ground and we had to
extend the street through visual effects
because there were some modern buildings
at the ends that we had a huge green
screen site at the end and here's more
like asses shopped in their armory Duffy
plays violet Miller a fellow laundry
worker who's actually already committed
suffragette and more looking out at the
debris of the attack
